comments:
Eclipse 200405060200
CDT     200405052036 (=~ 200405060200 + integration patches)

I can't reproduce this problem, but I was doing thing something like
creating, editing, building, then deleting a file in CDT.
Suddenly, I had an error dialog:

"An SWT error has occurred. You are recommended to exit the workbench."

Upon exit, my .log file contained:

SN, any idea why RemoveMenu would fail here?  The only hint that msdn gives, 
beyond passing an invalid handle or item id, is that a menu item with subitems 
will not be removed.

No idea.  Could be running out of resources.  I have noticed that the latest 
integration build hoses Windows out badly on occasion.

Nick, could the error message be changed to "An operating system error has 
occurred."  These kinds of errors don't come from SWT failing but rather the 
operating system running out of resources etc.  Thanks.

Brent, were you using detached views?  We saw another problem recently where
disposing a menu failed due to its shell being in a partially disposed state

Steve, do the NPEs in the other stacks above give any clue, or are they a result
of the earlier SWTError leaving SWT in a bad state?

Yes, that looks very suspicious.  When we reparent, we move menus across to 
the new shell and if we mess this up, the menu could be in 2 lists etc.  Do we 
have a repeatable case?

Hmmm... yes, I was playing with detached views recently.
Possibly in this session, but can't say for sure. Lemme retry...

Aha. Just got it again.... looks like exact same trace too...
C/C++ Projects view was redocked and I was just shuffling it around
within the left tab group...

Hmmm... Still not reproducible, though...

Here's something weird, possibly related, possibly red-herring.

Detach the left tab group and stretch it until all the buttons are
on the same line as the tab group.

Now drag one of the tabs (C/C++ Projects, or if you don't have
CDT you can fake it with the Navigator view) over each of the buttons.
Normally the proposed action is to move the dragged tab onto a new
detached view.  But once you hit the "Menu" button, the icon changes
and the proposed action is to shuffle the tab within the tab group.

When I caused the stack trace I wasn't in a detached view, but
you can see the "Menu" button does something different even when
not detached.  (The proposed actions are different when all docked.)
I could definitely have dragged onto the Menu button both times
I caused the stack trace.

There's still something else to reproducing this, but I think without
stepping through the code around the "Menu" button, I doubt I'll be able
to figure it out.

Created an attachment (id=10411)
CDT's left tab group

(Now try dragging the tab across the buttons, to the "Menu" button.)

Grant, can you get to the bottom of this and try to get a repeatable case?  
Thanks.

Although I don't have steps either, the problem most likely occurs if the
session was started with the view detached, then re-docked and manipulated.

Re: Comment 6 

This is probably unrelated. The weirdness you observe with drag-over affordances
on the toolbar comes from the strange widget hierarchy used for the workbench.
The drag/drop system uses the SWT widget hierarchy for inheriting drag over
affordances, but the toolbar is actually a peer with the tab folder, hence it
inherits drop behavior from higher up in the heirarchy.

I would normally use this as an excuse to plug the benefits of cross-platform
widget reparenting in SWT, but won't for fear of incurring the wrath of Steve. ;-)

Drag and drop is in inherited on any operating system.  Is this a concept that 
you added?

I have a simple reproduceable case involving detached views, using
I20040520-0800 + latest UI from head:

- new workspace
- dismiss intro
- in Navigator, pop up context menu and dismiss it
- detach Navigator
- pop up context menu and dismiss it

Upping severity since this is so easy to cause.


Full log follows.  You can ignore the first Runtime exception -- it's a
deliberate failure that comes from our test suite.

	at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.release(Display.java:2430)
	at org.eclipse.swt.graphics.Device.dispose(Device.java:216)
	at org.eclipse.ui.internal.ide.IDEApplication.run(IDEApplication.java:113)
	at
org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.PlatformActivator$1.run(PlatformActivator.java:307)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:256)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:127)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at
sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:324)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:185)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:638)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:622)

I was able to reproduce it on plain I20040520-0800 and I20040520-1921 builds as
well.  Strangely, I wasn't able to reproduce it in my development workspace
running I20040520-0800.

Brent, after bug 59780 I thought you were strictly an emacs man...

Also, I've been unable to reproduce this on 20040521-0010 using nick's steps 
from comment 12.
I'm also unable to reproduce using those steps.

I spoke too soon -- my last attempts were using the title bar's context menu.  
When I use the navigator's context menu I can reproduce the problem.  I'm 
running XP and was able to reproduce it with both the XP and win2K looks.

Fixed > 20040521

Renumber of the WM_COMMAND id's for Windows was moving the children before the 
parent items, thus invalidating the parent item when it was time for the 
parent to be renumbered.  The problem only happened in menus with submenus.

Nice sleuthing!
Thanks all.

Verified in RC2.

traces.message: The workbench should handle hostile pulldown delegates.
